1.verse: Job’s Life - A man named Job lived in Uz. He was a man of integrity: He was decent, he feared God, and he stayed away from evil.

2.verse: He had seven sons and three daughters.

3.verse: He owned 7,000 sheep and goats, 3,000 camels, 1,000 oxen, 500 donkeys, and a large number of servants. He was the most influential person in the Middle East.

4.verse: His sons used to go to each other’s homes, where they would have parties. (Each brother took his turn having a party.) They would send someone to invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

5.verse: When they finished having their parties, Job would send for them in order to cleanse them from sin. He would get up early in the morning and sacrifice burnt offerings for each of them. Job thought, “My children may have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Job offered sacrifices for them all the time.

6.verse: Satan Challenges the LORD - One day when the sons of God came to stand in front of the LORD, Satan the Accuser came along with them.

7.verse: The LORD asked Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan answered the LORD, “From wandering all over the earth.”

8.verse: The LORD asked Satan, “Have you thought about my servant Job? No one in the world is like him! He is a man of integrity: He is decent, he fears God, and he stays away from evil.”

9.verse: Satan answered the LORD, “Haven’t you given Job a reason to fear God?

10.verse: Haven’t you put a protective fence around him, his home, and everything he has? You have blessed everything he does. His cattle have spread out over the land.

11.verse: But now stretch out your hand, and strike everything he has. I bet he’ll curse you to your face.”

12.verse: The LORD told Satan, “Everything he has is in your power, but you must not lay a hand on him!” Then Satan left the LORD’s presence.

13.verse: Job’s First Crisis - One day when Job’s sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s home,

14.verse: a messenger came to Job. He said, “While the oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,

15.verse: men from Sheba attacked. They took the livestock and massacred the servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”

16.verse: While he was still speaking, another ⌞messenger⌟ came and said, “A fire from God fell from heaven and completely burned your flocks and servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”

17.verse: While he was still speaking, another ⌞messenger⌟ came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three companies and made a raid on the camels. They took the camels and massacred the servants. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”

18.verse: While he was still speaking, another ⌞messenger⌟ came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine at their oldest brother’s home

19.verse: when suddenly a great storm swept across the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It fell on the young people, and they died. I’m the only one who has escaped to tell you.”

20.verse: Job stood up, tore his robe in grief, and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground and worshiped.

21.verse: He said, “Naked I came from my mother, and naked I will return. The LORD has given, and the LORD has taken away! May the name of the LORD be praised.”

22.verse: Through all this Job did not sin or blame God for doing anything wrong.

1.verse: Satan Challenges the LORD Again - One day when the sons of God came to stand in front of the LORD, Satan the Accuser came along with them.

2.verse: The LORD asked Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan answered the LORD, “From wandering all over the earth.”

3.verse: The LORD asked Satan, “Have you thought about my servant Job? No one in the world is like him! He is a man of integrity: He is decent, he fears God, and he stays away from evil. And he still holds on to his principles. You’re trying to provoke me into ruining him for no reason.”

4.verse: Satan answered the LORD, “Skin for skin! Certainly, a man will give everything he has for his life.

5.verse: But stretch out your hand, and strike his flesh and bones. I bet he’ll curse you to your face.”

6.verse: The LORD told Satan, “He is in your power, but you must spare his life!”

7.verse: Job’s Second Crisis - Satan left the LORD’s presence and struck Job with painful boils from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.

8.verse: Job took a piece of broken pottery to scratch himself as he sat in the ashes.

9.verse: His wife asked him, “Are you still holding on to your principles? Curse God and die!”

10.verse: He said to her, “You’re talking like a godless fool. We accept the good that God gives us. Shouldn’t we also accept the bad?” Through all this Job’s lips did not utter one sinful word.

11.verse: When Job’s three friends heard about all the terrible things that had happened to him, each of them came from his home—Eliphaz of Teman, Bildad of Shuah, Zophar of Naama. They had agreed they would go together to sympathize with Job and comfort him.

12.verse: When they saw him from a distance, they didn’t even recognize him. They cried out loud and wept, and each of them tore his own clothes in grief. They threw dust on their heads.

13.verse: Then they sat down on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him because they saw that he was in such great pain.

1.verse: Job Speaks: Job Curses the Day He Was Born - After all this, Job ⌞finally⌟ opened his mouth and cursed the day he was born.

2.verse: Job said,

3.verse: “Scratch out the day I was born and the night that said, ‘A boy has been conceived!’

4.verse: “That day— let it be pitch-black. Let God above not ⌞even⌟ care about it. Let no light shine on it.

5.verse: Let the darkness and long shadows claim it as their own. Let a dark cloud hang over it. Let the gloom terrify it.

6.verse: “That night— let the blackness take it away. Let it not be included in the days of the year or be numbered among the months.

7.verse: Let that night be empty. Let no joyful singing be heard in it.

8.verse: Let those who curse the day  (those who know how to wake up Leviathan) curse that night.

9.verse: Let its stars turn dark before dawn. Let it hope for light and receive none. Let it not see the first light of dawn

10.verse: because it did not shut the doors of the womb ⌞from which I came⌟ or hide my eyes from trouble.

11.verse: Why Did I Survive at Birth? - “Why didn’t I die as soon as I was born and breathe my last breath when I came out of the womb?

12.verse: Why did knees welcome me? Why did breasts let me nurse?

13.verse: Instead of being alive, I would now be quietly lying down. I would now be sleeping peacefully.

14.verse: I would be with the kings and the counselors of the world who built for themselves ⌞what are now⌟ ruins.

15.verse: I would be with princes who had gold, who filled their homes with silver.

16.verse: I would be buried like a stillborn baby. I would not exist. I would be like infants who never saw the light.

17.verse: There the wicked stop their raging. There the weary are able to rest.

18.verse: There the captives have no troubles at all. There they do not hear the shouting of the slave driver.

19.verse: There ⌞you find⌟ both the unimportant and important people. There the slave is free from his master.

20.verse: Why Do I Go on Living? - “Why give light to one in misery and life to those who find it so bitter,

21.verse: to those who long for death but it never comes— though they dig for it more than for buried treasure?

22.verse: They are ecstatic, delighted to find the grave.

23.verse: Why give light to those whose paths have been hidden, to those whom God has fenced in?

24.verse: “When my food is in front of me, I sigh. I pour out my groaning like water.

25.verse: What I fear most overtakes me. What I dread happens to me.

26.verse: I have no peace! I have no quiet! I have no rest! And trouble keeps coming!”

1.verse: Eliphaz Speaks: Be Patient and Listen, Job - Then Eliphaz from Teman replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “If someone tries to talk to you, will you become impatient? But who can keep from talking?

3.verse: Certainly, you have instructed many people: When hands were weak, you made them strong.

4.verse: When someone stumbled, you lifted him up with your words. When knees were weak, you gave them strength.

5.verse: But trouble comes to you, and you’re impatient. It touches you, and you panic.

6.verse: Doesn’t your fear of God give you confidence and your lifetime of integrity give you hope?

7.verse: Only Evil People Suffer - “Now think about this: Which innocent person ⌞ever⌟ died ⌞an untimely death⌟? Find me a decent person who has been destroyed.

8.verse: Whenever I saw those who plowed wickedness and planted misery, they gathered its harvest.

9.verse: God destroys them with his breath and kills them with a blast of his anger.

10.verse: Though the roar of the lion and the growl of the ferocious lion ⌞is loud⌟, the young lions have had their teeth knocked out.

11.verse: The old lions die without any prey ⌞to eat⌟, and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.

12.verse: “I was told something secretly and heard something whispered in my ear.

13.verse: With disturbing thoughts from visions in the night, when deep sleep falls on people,

14.verse: fear and trembling came over me, and all my bones shook.

15.verse: A spirit passed in front of me. It made my hair stand on end.

16.verse: Something stood there. I couldn’t tell what it was. A vague image was in front of my eyes. I heard a soft voice:

17.verse: ‘Can ⌞any⌟ mortal be righteous to God? Can ⌞any⌟ human being be pure to his maker?’

18.verse: “You see, God doesn’t trust his own servants, and he accuses his angels of making mistakes.

19.verse: How much more will he accuse those who live in clay houses that have their foundation in the dust. Those houses can be crushed quicker than a moth!

20.verse: From morning to evening, they are shattered. They will disappear forever without anyone paying attention.

21.verse: Haven’t the ropes of their tent been loosened? Won’t they die without wisdom?

1.verse: Eliphaz Continues: Seek God’s Help, Job - “Cry out! Is there anyone to answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?

2.verse: Certainly, anger kills a stubborn fool, and jealousy murders a gullible person.

3.verse: I have seen a stubborn fool take root, but I quickly cursed his house.

4.verse: His children are far from help. They are crushed at the city gate, and no one is there to rescue them.

5.verse: What a stubborn fool gathers, hungry people eat. They take it even from among the thorns, and thirsty people pant after his wealth.

6.verse: Certainly, sorrow doesn’t come from the soil, and trouble doesn’t sprout from the ground.

7.verse: But a person is born for trouble as surely as sparks fly up ⌞from a fire⌟.

8.verse: “But I would seek God’s help and present my case to him.

9.verse: He does great things that ⌞we⌟ cannot understand and miracles that ⌞we⌟ cannot count.

10.verse: He gives rain to the earth and sends water to the fields.

11.verse: He places lowly people up high. He lifts those who mourn to safety.

12.verse: He keeps shrewd people from carrying out their plans so that they cannot do anything successfully.

13.verse: He catches the wise with their own tricks. The plans of schemers prove to be hasty.

14.verse: In the daytime they meet darkness and grope in the sunlight as if it were night.

15.verse: “But he saves ⌞other people⌟ from their slander and the needy from the power of the mighty.

16.verse: Then the poor have hope while wrongdoing shuts its mouth.

17.verse: Blessing Comes When God Corrects You - “Blessed is the person whom God corrects. That person should not despise discipline from the Almighty.

18.verse: God injures, but he bandages. He beats you up, but his hands make you well.

19.verse: He will keep you safe from six troubles, and when the seventh one comes, no harm will touch you:

20.verse: “In famine he will save you from death, and in war he will save you from the sword.

21.verse: “When the tongue lashes out, you will be safe, and you will not be afraid of destruction when it comes.

22.verse: “You will be able to laugh at destruction and starvation, so do not be afraid of wild animals on the earth.

23.verse: “You will have a binding agreement with the stones in the field, and wild animals will be at peace with you.

24.verse: “You will know peace in your tent. You will inspect your house and find nothing missing.

25.verse: “You will find that your children are many and your descendants are like the grass of the earth.

26.verse: “You will come to your grave at a ripe old age like a stack of hay in the right season.

27.verse: “We have studied all of this thoroughly! This is the way it is. Listen to it, and learn it for yourself.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: God Has Attacked Me Without Cause - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “If only my grief could be weighed, if only my misery could be laid on the scales with it,

3.verse: then they would be heavier than the sand of the seas. I spoke carelessly

4.verse: because the arrows of the Almighty ⌞have found their target⌟ in me, and my spirit is drinking their poison. God’s terrors line up in battle against me.

5.verse: “Does a wild donkey bray when it’s ⌞eating⌟ grass, or does an ox make a sound over its hay?

6.verse: Is tasteless food eaten without salt, or is there any flavor in the white of an egg?

7.verse: I refuse to touch such things. They are disgusting to me.

8.verse: “How I wish that my prayer would be answered— that God would give me what I’m hoping for,

9.verse: that God would ⌞finally⌟ be willing to crush me, that he would reach out to cut me off.

10.verse: Then I would still have comfort. I would be happy despite my endless pain, because I have not rejected the words of the Holy One.

11.verse: What strength do I have ⌞left⌟ that I can go on hoping? What goal do I have that I would want to prolong my life?

12.verse: Do I have the strength of rocks? Does my body have the strength of bronze?

13.verse: Am I not completely helpless? Haven’t my skills been taken away from me?

14.verse: You Have Not Treated Me Like True Friends - “A friend should treat a troubled person kindly, even if he abandons the fear of the Almighty.

15.verse: My brothers have been as deceptive as seasonal rivers, like the seasonal riverbeds that flood.

16.verse: They are dark with ice. They are hidden by snow.

17.verse: They vanish during a scorching summer. In the heat their riverbeds dry up.

18.verse: They change their course. They go into a wasteland and disappear.

19.verse: Caravans from Tema look for them. Travelers from Sheba search for them.

20.verse: They are ashamed because they relied on the streams. Arriving there, they are disappointed.

21.verse: “So you are as unreliable to me ⌞as they are⌟. You see something terrifying, and you are afraid.

22.verse: Did I ever say, ‘Give me a gift,’ or ‘Offer me a bribe from your wealth,’

23.verse: or ‘Rescue me from an enemy,’ or ‘Ransom me from a tyrant’?

24.verse: Teach me, and I’ll be silent. Show me where I’ve been wrong.

25.verse: How painful an honest discussion can be! In correcting me, you correct yourselves!

26.verse: Do you think my words need correction? Do you think they’re what a desperate person says to the wind?

27.verse: Would you also throw dice for an orphan? Would you buy and sell your friend?

28.verse: “But now, if you’re willing, look at me. I won’t lie to your face.

29.verse: Please change your mind. Don’t permit any injustice. Change your mind because I am still right about this!

30.verse: Is there injustice on my tongue, or is my mouth unable to tell the difference between right and wrong?

1.verse: Job Speaks about the Futility of Human Existence - “Isn’t a mortal’s stay on earth difficult like a hired hand’s daily ⌞work⌟?

2.verse: Like a slave, he longs for shade. Like a hired hand, he eagerly looks for his pay.

3.verse: Likewise, I have been given months that are of no use, and I have inherited nights filled with misery.

4.verse: When I lie down, I ask, ‘When will I get up?’ But the evening is long, and I’m exhausted from tossing about until dawn.

5.verse: My body is covered with maggots and scabs. My skin is crusted over with sores; then they ooze.

6.verse: My days go swifter than a weaver’s shuttle. They are spent without hope.

7.verse: Remember, my life is only a breath, and never again will my eyes see anything good.

8.verse: The eye that watches over me will no longer see me. Your eye will look for me, but I’ll be gone.

9.verse: As a cloud fades away and disappears, so a person goes into the grave and doesn’t come back again.

10.verse: He doesn’t come back home again, and his household doesn’t recognize him anymore.

11.verse: So I won’t keep my mouth shut, but I will speak from the distress that is in my spirit and complain about the bitterness in my soul.

12.verse: Job Says to God: Leave Me Alone - “Am I the sea or a sea monster that you have set a guard over me?

13.verse: When I say, ‘My couch may give me comfort. My bed may help me bear my pain,’

14.verse: then you frighten me with dreams and terrify me with visions.

15.verse: My throat would rather be choked. My body  would prefer death ⌞to these dreams⌟.

16.verse: I hate my life; I do not want to live forever. Leave me alone because my days are so brief.

17.verse: “What is a mortal that you should make so much of him, that you should be concerned about him?

18.verse: ⌞What is he⌟ that you should inspect him every morning and examine him every moment?

19.verse: Why don’t you stop looking at me long enough to let me swallow my spit?

20.verse: If I sin, what can I ⌞possibly⌟ do to you since you insist on spying on people? Why do you make me your target? I’ve become a burden even to myself.

21.verse: Why don’t you forgive my disobedience and take away my sin? Soon I’ll lie down in the dust. Then you will search for me, but I’ll be gone!”

1.verse: Bildad Speaks: You Are Unjustly Accusing God of Doing Evil, Job - Then Bildad from Shuah replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “How long will you say these things? How long will your words be so windy?

3.verse: Does God distort justice, or does the Almighty distort righteousness?

4.verse: If your children sinned against him, he allowed them to suffer the consequences of their sinfulness.

5.verse: If you search for God and plead for mercy from the Almighty,

6.verse: if you are moral and ethical, then he will rise up on your behalf and prove your righteousness by rebuilding your home.

7.verse: Then what you had in the past will seem small compared with the great prosperity you’ll have in the future.

8.verse: Learn from Past Generations - “Ask the people of past generations. Find out what their ancestors had learned.

9.verse: We have only been around since yesterday, and we know nothing. Our days on earth are only a fleeting shadow.

10.verse: Won’t their words teach you? Won’t they share their thoughts with you?

11.verse: God Does Not Punish the Innocent Person - “Can papyrus grow up where there is no swamp? Can rushes grow tall without water?

12.verse: Even if they were fresh and not cut, they would wither quicker than grass.

13.verse: The same thing happens to all who forget God. The hope of the godless dies.

14.verse: His confidence is easily shattered. His trust is a spider’s web.

15.verse: If one leans on his house, it collapses. If one holds on to it, it will not support his weight.

16.verse: He is like a well-watered plant in the sunshine. The shoots spread over his garden.

17.verse: Its roots weave through a pile of stones. They cling to a stone house.

18.verse: But when it is uprooted from its place, ⌞the ground⌟ denies it ⌞and says⌟, ‘I never saw you!’

19.verse: That is its joy in this life, and others sprout from the same ground to ⌞take its place⌟.

20.verse: “Certainly, God does not reject a person of integrity or give a helping hand to wicked people.

21.verse: He will fill your mouth with laughter and your lips with happy shouting.

22.verse: Those who hate you will be clothed with shame, and the tent of the wicked will cease to exist.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: the Futility of Arguing with God - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “Yes, I know that this is true. But how can a mortal be declared righteous to God?

3.verse: If he wished to debate with God, he wouldn’t be able to answer one question in a thousand.

4.verse: “God is wise in heart and mighty in power. Who could oppose him and win?

5.verse: He moves mountains without their knowing it, and he topples them in his anger.

6.verse: He shakes the earth from its place, and its pillars tremble.

7.verse: He commands the sun not to rise. He doesn’t let the stars come out.

8.verse: He stretches out the heavens by himself and walks on the waves of the sea.

9.verse: He made ⌞the constellations⌟ Ursa Major, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the clusters of stars in the south.

10.verse: He does great things that are unsearchable and miracles that cannot be numbered.

11.verse: He passes alongside of me, and I don’t even see him. He goes past me, and I don’t even notice him.

12.verse: He takes something away, ⌞but⌟ who can stop him? Who is going to ask him, ‘What are you doing?’

13.verse: God does not hold back his anger. Even Rahab’s helpers bow humbly in front of him.

14.verse: “How can I possibly answer God? How can I find the right words ⌞to speak⌟ with him?

15.verse: Even if I were right, I could not answer ⌞him⌟. I would have to plead for mercy from my judge.

16.verse: If I cried out and he answered me, I do not believe that he would listen to me.

17.verse: He would knock me down with a storm and bruise me without a reason.

18.verse: He would not let me catch my breath. He fills me with bitterness.

19.verse: If it is a matter of strength, then he is the mighty one. If it is about justice, who will charge me with a crime?

20.verse: If I am righteous, my own mouth would condemn me. It would declare that I am corrupt even if I am a man of integrity.

21.verse: If I am a man of integrity, I have no way of knowing it. I hate my life!

22.verse: It is all the same. That is why I say, ‘He destroys ⌞both⌟ the man of integrity and the wicked.’

23.verse: When a sudden disaster brings death, he makes fun of the despair of innocent people.

24.verse: The earth is handed over to the wicked. He covers the faces of its judges. If he isn’t the one ⌞doing this⌟, who is?

25.verse: “My days go by more quickly than a runner. They sprint away. They don’t see anything good.

26.verse: They pass by quickly like boats made from reeds, like an eagle swooping down on its prey.

27.verse: ⌞Even⌟ if I say, ‘I will forget my complaining; I will change my expression and smile,’

28.verse: I ⌞still⌟ dread everything I must suffer. I know that you won’t declare me innocent.

29.verse: I’ve already been found guilty. Why should I work so hard for nothing?

30.verse: If I wash myself with lye soap and cleanse my hands with bleach,

31.verse: then you would plunge me into a muddy pit, and my own clothes would find me disgusting.

32.verse: A human like me cannot answer God, ‘Let’s take our case to court.’

33.verse: There is no mediator between us to put his hand on both of us.

34.verse: God should take his rod away from me, and he should not terrify me.

35.verse: Then I would speak and not be afraid of him. But I know that I am not like that.

1.verse: Job Says to God: I Hate My Life - “I hate my life. I will freely express my complaint. I will speak as bitterly as I feel.

2.verse: I will say to God, ‘Don’t condemn me. Let me know why you are quarreling with me.

3.verse: What do you gain by mistreating me, by rejecting the work of your hands while you favor the plans of the wicked?

4.verse: Do you actually have human eyes? Do you see as a mortal sees?

5.verse: Are your days like a mortal’s days? Are your years like a human’s years?

6.verse: Is that why you look for guilt in me and search for sin in me?

7.verse: You know I’m not guilty, but there is no one to rescue me from your hands.

8.verse: “ ‘Your hands formed me and made every part of me, then you turned to destroy me.

9.verse: Please remember that you made me out of clay and that you will return me to the dust again.

10.verse: Didn’t you pour me out like milk and curdle me like cheese?

11.verse: Didn’t you dress me in skin and flesh and weave me together with bones and tendons?

12.verse: You gave me life and mercy. Your watchfulness has preserved my spirit.

13.verse: But in your heart you hid these things. I know this is what you did.

14.verse: “ ‘If I sin, you watch me and will not free me from my guilt.

15.verse: How terrible it will be for me if I’m guilty! Even if I’m righteous, I dare not lift up my head. I am filled with disgrace while I look on my misery.

16.verse: Like a proud, ferocious lion you hunt me down. You keep working your miracles against me.

17.verse: You keep finding new witnesses against me. You keep increasing your anger toward me. You keep bringing new armies against me.

18.verse: “ ‘Why did you take me out of the womb? I wish I had breathed my last breath before anyone had laid eyes on me.

19.verse: Then it would be as if I had never existed, as if I had been carried from the womb to the tomb.

20.verse: “ ‘Isn’t my life short enough? So stop ⌞this⌟, and leave me alone. Let me smile a little

21.verse: before I go away to a land of darkness and gloom,

22.verse: to a dismal land of long shadows and confusion where light is as bright as darkness. I’ll never return.’ ”

1.verse: Zophar Speaks: Your Words Call for an Answer, Job - Then Zophar from Naama replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “Shouldn’t someone answer this flood of words? Should a good public speaker be acquitted?

3.verse: Should your empty talk silence others so that you can make fun of us without any shame?

4.verse: You say, ‘My teaching is morally correct,’ and, ‘As you can see, I’m innocent.’

5.verse: I only wish God would speak and open his mouth ⌞to talk⌟ to you.

6.verse: He would tell you the secrets of wisdom, because ⌞true⌟ wisdom is twice ⌞as great as your wisdom⌟, and you would know that God forgets your sin.

7.verse: God Can Do as He Pleases - “Can you discover God’s hidden secrets, or are you able to find the Almighty’s limits?

8.verse: ⌞God’s wisdom is⌟ higher than heaven. What can you do? It is deeper than ⌞the depths⌟ of hell. What can you know?

9.verse: It is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.

10.verse: If God comes along and imprisons ⌞someone⌟ and then calls a court into session, who can stop him?

11.verse: He knows who the scoundrels are. And when he sees sin, doesn’t he pay attention to it?

12.verse: But an empty-headed person will gain understanding when a wild donkey is born tame.

13.verse: Confess Your Sin and Be Forgiven - “If you want to set your heart right, then pray to him.

14.verse: If you’re holding on to sin, put it far away, and don’t let injustice live in your tent.

15.verse: Then you will be able to show your face without being ashamed, and you will be secure and unafraid.

16.verse: ⌞Then⌟ you will forget your misery and remember it like water that has flowed downstream.

17.verse: Then your life will be brighter than the noonday sun. The darkness in your life will become like morning.

18.verse: You will feel confident because there’s hope, and you will look around and rest in safety.

19.verse: You will lie down with no one to frighten you, and many people will try to gain your favor.

20.verse: But the wicked will lose their eyesight. Their escape route will be closed. Their only hope is to take their last breath.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: My Friends Have No Wisdom - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “You certainly are ⌞wise⌟ people, and when you die, wisdom will die.

3.verse: Like you, I have a mind. I am not inferior to you. But who doesn’t know these things?

4.verse: I am a laughingstock to my neighbors. I am one who calls on God and expects an answer. A man of integrity, a man who is righteous, has become a laughingstock.

5.verse: “A person who has an easy life has no appreciation for misfortune. He thinks it is the fate of those who slip up.

6.verse: ⌞But⌟ robbers’ tents are prosperous, and there is security for those who provoke God, for those whose god is their power.

7.verse: “Instead, ask the animals, and they will teach you. Ask the birds, and they will tell you.

8.verse: Or speak with the earth, and it will teach you. Even the fish will relate ⌞the story⌟ to you.

9.verse: What creature doesn’t know that the LORD’s hands made it?

10.verse: The life of every living creature and the spirit in every human body are in his hands.

11.verse: Doesn’t the ear distinguish sounds and the tongue taste food?

12.verse: Wisdom Comes from God - “Wisdom is with the ancient one. The one who has had many days has insight.

13.verse: God has wisdom and strength. Advice and insight are his.

14.verse: When he tears ⌞something⌟ down, it cannot be rebuilt. When he puts someone in prison, that person cannot be freed.

15.verse: When he holds back the waters, there is a drought. When he releases them, they flood the earth.

16.verse: “God has power and priceless wisdom. He owns ⌞both⌟ the deceiver and the person who is deceived.

17.verse: He leads counselors away barefoot and makes fools out of judges.

18.verse: He loosens kings’ belts and strips them of their pants.

19.verse: He leads priests away barefoot and misleads those who serve in a temple.

20.verse: He makes trusted advisers unable to speak and takes away the good judgment of respected leaders.

21.verse: He pours contempt on influential people and unbuckles the belt of the mighty.

22.verse: He uncovers mysteries ⌞hidden⌟ in the darkness and brings gloom into the light.

23.verse: He makes nations important and then destroys them. He makes nations large and leads them away.

24.verse: He takes away the common sense of a country’s leaders and makes them stumble about in a pathless wilderness.

25.verse: They grope in the dark with no light, and he makes them stumble like drunks.

1.verse: Job Continues: You Are Not Listening to Me - “My eye has certainly seen all of this! My ear has heard and understood it.

2.verse: After all, I know it as well as you do. I am not inferior to you.

3.verse: However, I want to speak to the Almighty, and I wish to argue my case in front of God.

4.verse: But you are smearing me with lies. All of you are worthless physicians.

5.verse: I wish you would keep silent. For you, that would be wisdom.

6.verse: Please listen to my argument, and pay attention to my plea.

7.verse: Your Wisdom Misrepresents God - “Will you talk wickedly for God and talk deceitfully on his behalf?

8.verse: Will you favor him ⌞as⌟ if you were arguing in court on God’s behalf?

9.verse: Will it go well when he cross-examines you? Will you try to trick him as one mortal tricks another?

10.verse: Will he really defend you if you secretly favor ⌞him⌟?

11.verse: Doesn’t his majesty terrify you? Doesn’t the fear of him fall upon you?

12.verse: “Your recollections are worthless proverbs. Your answers are absolutely useless.

13.verse: Be quiet, because I want to speak. Let whatever may happen to me ⌞happen⌟!

14.verse: I am biting off more than I can chew and taking my life in my own hands.

15.verse: If God would kill me, I would have no hope ⌞left⌟. Nevertheless, I will defend my behavior to his face.

16.verse: This also will be my salvation because no godless person could face him.

17.verse: Job Speaks to God - “Listen carefully to my words. Hear my declaration.

18.verse: I have prepared my case. I know that I will be declared righteous.

19.verse: Who can make a case against me? If someone could, I’d be silent and die.

20.verse: “Please don’t do two things to me so that I won’t have to hide from you:

21.verse: Stop oppressing me. Don’t let your terror frighten me.

22.verse: Then call, and I’ll answer. Otherwise, I’ll speak, and you’ll answer me.

23.verse: How many crimes and sins have I committed? Make me aware of my disobedience and my sin.

24.verse: Why do you hide your face ⌞from me⌟ and consider me your enemy?

25.verse: Are you trying to make a fluttering leaf tremble or trying to chase dry husks?

26.verse: You write down bitter accusations against me. You make me suffer for the sins of my youth.

27.verse: You put my feet in shackles. You follow my trail by engraving marks on the soles of my feet.

28.verse: I am like worn-out wineskins, like moth-eaten clothes.

1.verse: Job Continues: Consider My Frail Human Nature, God - “A person who is born of a woman is short-lived and is full of trouble.

2.verse: He comes up like a flower; then he withers. He is like a fleeting shadow; he doesn’t stay long.

3.verse: You observe this and call me to account to you.

4.verse: “If only an unclean person could become clean! It’s not possible.

5.verse: If the number of his days and the number of his months are determined by you, and you set his limit, then he cannot go past it.

6.verse: Look away from him, and he will cease to be. Meanwhile, he loves life as a laborer loves work.

7.verse: There is hope for a tree when it is cut down. It will sprout again. Its shoots will not stop sprouting.

8.verse: If its roots grow old in the ground and its stump dies in the soil,

9.verse: merely a scent of water will make it sprout and grow branches like a plant.

10.verse: But a human dies and is powerless. A person breathes his last breath, and where is he?

11.verse: ⌞As⌟ water drains out of a lake, or ⌞as⌟ a river dries up completely,

12.verse: so each person lies down and does not rise until the heavens cease to exist. He does not wake up. He is not awakened from his sleep.

13.verse: I wish you would hide me in Sheol and keep me hidden there until your anger cools. Set a specific time for me when you will remember me.

14.verse: “If a person dies, will he go on living? I will wait for my relief to come as long as my hard labor continues.

15.verse: You will call, and I will answer you. You will long for the person your hands have made.

16.verse: Though now you count my steps, you will not keep ⌞a record of⌟ my sins.

17.verse: My disobedience will be closed up in a bag, and you will cover over my sins.

18.verse: As surely as a mountain falls and rocks are dislodged,

19.verse: ⌞so⌟ water wears away stone, floods wash away soil from the land, and you destroy a mortal’s hope.

20.verse: You overpower him forever, and he passes away. You change his appearance and send him away.

21.verse: His sons are honored, and he doesn’t know it. Or they become unimportant, and he doesn’t realize it.

22.verse: He feels only his body’s pain. He is only worried about himself.”

1.verse: Eliphaz Speaks: You Are Speaking Sinfully, Job - Then Eliphaz from Teman replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “Should a wise person answer with endless details and fill his stomach with the east wind?

3.verse: Should he argue with words that don’t help, with speeches that don’t help ⌞anyone⌟?

4.verse: Yes, you destroy the fear ⌞of God⌟ and diminish devotion to God.

5.verse: Your sin teaches you what to say. You choose ⌞to talk with⌟ a sly tongue.

6.verse: Your ⌞own⌟ mouth condemns you, not I. Your lips testify against you.

7.verse: You Are Not the Only Wise Person, Job - “Were you the first human to be born? Were you delivered before the hills ⌞existed⌟?

8.verse: Did you listen in on God’s council meeting and receive a monopoly on wisdom?

9.verse: What do you know that we don’t know? What do you understand that we don’t?

10.verse: Both the old and the gray-haired are among us. They are older than your father.

11.verse: Isn’t God’s comfort enough for you, even when gently spoken to you?

12.verse: Why have your emotions carried you away? Why do your eyes flash

13.verse: when you turn against God and spit these words out of your mouth?

14.verse: Why should a mortal be considered faultless or someone born of a woman be considered righteous?

15.verse: If God doesn’t trust his holy ones, and the heavens are not pure in his sight,

16.verse: how much less will he trust the one who is disgusting and corrupt, the one who drinks wickedness like water.

17.verse: I Want to Tell You What I Know - “I’ll tell you; listen to me! I’ll relate what I have seen.

18.verse: I’ll tell you what wise people have declared and what was not kept secret from their ancestors.

19.verse: (The land was given to them alone, and no stranger passed through their land.)

20.verse: The Tortured Life of the Wicked Person - “The wicked person is tortured all his days. Only a few years are reserved for the ruthless person.

21.verse: Terrifying sounds are in his ears. While he enjoys peace, the destroyer comes to him.

22.verse: He doesn’t believe he’ll return from the dark. He is destined ⌞to be killed⌟ with a sword.

23.verse: He wanders around for food and asks, ‘Where is it?’ He knows that his ruin is close at hand.

24.verse: “The day of darkness troubles him. Distress and anguish terrify him like a king ready for battle.

25.verse: He stretches out his hand against God and attacks the Almighty like a warrior.

26.verse: He stubbornly charges at him with a thick shield.

27.verse: “His face is bloated with fat, and he is fat around the waist.

28.verse: He lives in ruined cities where no one dwells, in houses that are doomed to be piles of rubble.

29.verse: He won’t get rich, and his wealth won’t last. His possessions won’t spread out over the land.

30.verse: “He won’t escape the darkness. A flame will shrivel his branches. He will be blown away by his own breath.

31.verse: He shouldn’t trust in worthless things and deceive himself because he will get worthless things in return.

32.verse: It will happen before his time has come, and his branch will not become green.

33.verse: He will drop his unripened grapes like a vine and throw off his blossoms like an olive tree

34.verse: because a mob of godless people produces nothing, and fire burns up the tents of those who offer bribes.

35.verse: They conceive trouble and give birth to evil. Their wombs produce deception.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: My Friends Do Not Help Ease My Pain - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “I have heard many things like this before. You are all pathetic at comforting me.

3.verse: Will ⌞your⌟ long-winded speeches never end? What disturbs you that you keep on answering ⌞me⌟?

4.verse: I, too, could speak like you if we could trade places. I could string words together against you and shake my head at you.

5.verse: I could encourage you with my mouth, and my quivering lips could ease ⌞your pain⌟.

6.verse: If I speak, my pain is not eased. If I stop talking, how much of it will go away?

7.verse: “But now, God has worn me out. You, ⌞God,⌟ have destroyed everyone who supports me.

8.verse: You have shriveled me up, which itself is a witness ⌞against me⌟. My frail body rises up and testifies against me.

9.verse: Job Describes What God Has Done to Him - “God’s anger tore me ⌞apart⌟ and attacked me. He gritted his teeth at me. My opponent looked sharply at me.

10.verse: People ridiculed me with their mouths. They slapped my cheeks with contempt. They united against me.

11.verse: God handed me over to unjust people and threw me into the hands of wicked people.

12.verse: I was at ease, and he shattered me. He grabbed me by the back of the neck and smashed ⌞my skull⌟. He set me up as his target,

13.verse: and his archers surrounded me. He slashes open my kidneys without mercy and spills my blood on the ground.

14.verse: He inflicts wound after wound on me. He lunges at me like a warrior.

15.verse: “I have sewn sackcloth over my skin, and I have thrown my strength in the dust.

16.verse: My face is red from crying, and dark shadows encircle my eyes,

17.verse: although my hands have done nothing violent, and my prayer is sincere.

18.verse: Job Appeals His Case to Heaven - “Earth, don’t cover my blood. Don’t ever let my cry ⌞for justice⌟ be stopped.

19.verse: Even now, look! My witness is in heaven, and the one who testifies for me is above,

20.verse: the spokesman for my thoughts. My eyes drip ⌞with tears⌟ to God

21.verse: But my witness will plead for a human in front of God. The Son of Man will plead for his friend!

22.verse: because in a few short years I will take the path of no return.

1.verse: Job Pleads with God to Declare Him Honest - “My spirit is broken. My days have been snuffed out. The cemetery ⌞is waiting⌟ for me.

2.verse: Certainly, mockers are around me. My eyes are focused on their opposition.

3.verse: Please guarantee my bail yourself. Who else will guarantee it with a handshake?

4.verse: You have closed their minds so that they cannot understand. That is why you will not honor them.

5.verse: (Whoever turns in friends to get their property should have his children’s eyesight fail.)

6.verse: Job Says to His Friends: I’m Still Wiser Than You - “Now he has made me a laughingstock for many people. Now they spit in my face.

7.verse: Now my eyes are blurred from grief. Now all my limbs are like a shadow.

8.verse: Decent people are shocked by this, and it stirs up the innocent against godless people.

9.verse: Yet, the righteous person clings to his way, and the one with clean hands grows stronger.

10.verse: “But now, all of you, come and try again! I won’t find one wise man among you.

11.verse: My days are passing by. My plans are broken. My dreams ⌞are shattered⌟.

12.verse: You say that night is day. Light has nearly become darkness.

13.verse: If I look for the grave as my home and make my bed in the darkness,

14.verse: if I say to the pit, ‘You are my father,’ and to the worm, ‘You are my mother and sister,’

15.verse: then where is my hope? Can you see any hope left in me?

16.verse: Will hope go down with me to the gates of the grave? Will my hope rest with me in the dust?”

1.verse: Bildad Speaks: Why Do You Think You Are So Great, Job? - Then Bildad from Shuah replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “How long before your words will end? Think it through, and then we’ll talk.

3.verse: Why do you think of us as cattle? Why are we considered stupid in your eyes?

4.verse: Why do you rip yourself apart in anger? Should the earth be abandoned for your sake or a boulder be dislodged?

5.verse: What a Wicked Person Can Expect from Life - “Indeed, the light of the wicked is snuffed out. The flame of his fire stops glowing.

6.verse: The light in his tent becomes dark, and the lamp above him is snuffed out.

7.verse: “His healthy stride is shortened, and his own planning trips him up.

8.verse: His own feet get him tangled in a net as he walks around on its webbing.

9.verse: A trap catches his heel. A snare holds him.

10.verse: A rope is hidden on the ground for him. A trap is on his path ⌞to catch⌟ him.

11.verse: “Terrors suddenly pounce on him from every side and chase him every step he takes.

12.verse: Hunger undermines his strength. Disaster is waiting beside him.

13.verse: His skin is eaten away by disease. Death’s firstborn son eats away at the limbs of his body.

14.verse: He is dragged from the safety of his tent and marched off to the king of terrors.

15.verse: Fire lives in his tent. Sulfur is scattered over his home.

16.verse: His roots dry up under him. His branches wither over him.

17.verse: All memory about him will vanish from the earth, and his reputation will not be known on the street corner.

18.verse: He will be driven from the light into the dark and chased out of the world.

19.verse: He will not have any children or descendants among his people or any survivor where he used to live.

20.verse: People in the west are shocked by what happens to him. People in the east are seized with horror.

21.verse: This is what happens to the homes of wicked people and to those who do not know God.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: Admit That God Is Mistreating Me - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “How long will you torment me and depress me with words?

3.verse: You have insulted me ten times now. You’re not even ashamed of mistreating me.

4.verse: Even if it were true that I’ve made a mistake without realizing it, my mistake would affect only me.

5.verse: If you are trying to make yourselves look better than me by using my disgrace as an argument against me,

6.verse: then I want you to know that God has wronged me and surrounded me with his net.

7.verse: Indeed, I cry, ‘Help! I’m being attacked!’ but I get no response. I call for help, but there is no justice.

8.verse: What God Has Done to Me - “God has blocked my path so that I can’t go on. He has made my paths dark.

9.verse: He has stripped me of my honor. He has taken the crown off my head.

10.verse: He beats me down on every side until I’m gone. He uproots my hope like a tree.

11.verse: He is very angry at me. He considers me to be his enemy.

12.verse: His troops assemble against me. They build a ramp to attack me and camp around my tent.

13.verse: “My brothers stay far away from me. My friends are complete strangers to me.

14.verse: My relatives and my closest friends have stopped coming. My house guests have forgotten me.

15.verse: My female slaves consider me to be a stranger. I am like a foreigner to them.

16.verse: I call my slave, but he doesn’t answer, though I beg him.

17.verse: My breath offends my wife. I stink to my own children.

18.verse: Even young children despise me. If I stand up, they make fun of me.

19.verse: All my closest friends are disgusted with me. Those I love have turned against me.

20.verse: I am skin and bones, and I have escaped only by the skin of my teeth.

21.verse: “Have pity on me, my friends! Have pity on me because God’s hand has struck me down.

22.verse: Why do you pursue me as God does? Why are you never satisfied with my flesh?

23.verse: Job’s Confidence in His Defender - “I wish now my words were written. I wish they were inscribed on a scroll.

24.verse: I wish they were forever engraved on a rock with an iron stylus and lead.

25.verse: But I know that my defender lives, and afterwards, he will rise on the earth.

26.verse: Even after my skin has been stripped off my body, I will see God in my own flesh.

27.verse: I will see him with my own eyes, not with someone else’s. My heart fails inside me!

28.verse: Job Warns His Friends - “You say, ‘We will persecute him! The root of the problem is found in him.’

29.verse: Fear death, because ⌞your anger⌟ is punishable by death. Then you will know there is a judge.”

1.verse: Zophar Speaks: Here Is My Answer - Then Zophar from Naama replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “My disturbing thoughts make me answer, and because of them I am upset.

3.verse: I have heard criticism that makes me ashamed, but a spirit beyond my understanding gives me answers.

4.verse: A Wicked Person’s Joy Is Short, His Pain Long - “Don’t you know that from ancient times, from the time humans were placed on earth,

5.verse: the triumph of the wicked is short-lived, and the joy of the godless person lasts only a moment?

6.verse: If his height reaches to the sky and his head touches the clouds,

7.verse: he will certainly rot like his own feces. Those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’

8.verse: He will fly away like a dream and not be found. He will be chased away like a vision in the night.

9.verse: Eyes that saw him will see him no more. His home will not look at him again.

10.verse: His children will have to ask the poor for help. His own hands will have to give back his wealth.

11.verse: His bones, once full of youthful vigor, will lie down with him in the dust.

12.verse: “Though evil is sweet in his mouth and he hides it under his tongue….

13.verse: Though he savors it and won’t let go of it and he holds it on the roof of his mouth,

14.verse: the food in his belly turns sour. It becomes snake venom in his stomach.

15.verse: He vomits up the riches that he swallowed. God forces them out of his stomach.

16.verse: The godless person sucks the poison of snakes. A viper’s fang kills him.

17.verse: He won’t be able to drink from the streams or from the rivers of honey and buttermilk.

18.verse: He will give back what he earned without enjoying it. He will get no joy from the profits of his business

19.verse: because he crushed and abandoned the poor. He has taken by force a house that he didn’t build.

20.verse: He will never know peace in his heart. He will never allow anything he desires to escape ⌞his grasp⌟.

21.verse: “Nothing is left for him to eat. His prosperity won’t last.

22.verse: ⌞Even⌟ with all his wealth the full force of misery comes down on him.

23.verse: Let that misery fill his belly. ⌞God⌟ throws his burning anger at the godless person and makes his wrath come down on him like rain.

24.verse: If that person flees from an iron weapon, a bronze bow will pierce him.

25.verse: He pulls it out, and it comes out of his back. The glittering point comes out of his gallbladder. “Terrors come quickly to the godless person:

26.verse: Total darkness waits in hiding for his treasure. A fire that no one fans will burn him. Whatever is left in his tent will be devoured.

27.verse: Heaven exposes his sin. Earth rises up against him.

28.verse: A flood will sweep away his house, a flash flood on the day of his anger.

29.verse: This is the reward God gives to the wicked person, the inheritance God has appointed for him.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: Comfort Me by Listening to Me - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “Listen carefully to my words, and let that be the comfort you offer me.

3.verse: Bear with me while I speak. Then after I’ve spoken, you may go on mocking.

4.verse: Am I complaining about a person? Why shouldn’t I be impatient?

5.verse: Look at me, and be shocked, and put ⌞your⌟ hand over ⌞your⌟ mouth.

6.verse: When I remember it, I’m terrified, and shuddering seizes my body.

7.verse: Wicked People Do Not Suffer for Their Sins - “Why do the wicked go on living, grow old, and even become more powerful?

8.verse: They see their children firmly established with them, and they get to see their descendants.

9.verse: Their homes are free from fear, and God doesn’t use his rod on them.

10.verse: Their bulls are fertile when they breed. Their cows give birth to calves and never miscarry.

11.verse: They send their little children out ⌞to play⌟ like a flock of lambs, and their children dance around.

12.verse: They sing with the tambourine and lyre, and they are happy with the music of the flute.

13.verse: They spend their days in happiness, and they go peacefully to the grave.

14.verse: But they say to God, ‘Leave us alone. We don’t want to know your ways.

15.verse: Who is the Almighty that we should serve him? What do we gain if we pray to him?’

16.verse: Anyhow, isn’t their happiness in their own power? (The plan of the wicked is foreign to my way of thinking.)

17.verse: “How often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out? How often does disaster happen to them? How often does an angry God give them pain?

18.verse: How often are they like straw in the wind or like husks that the storm sweeps away?

19.verse: “⌞You say,⌟ ‘God saves a person’s punishment for his children.’ God should pay back that person so that he would know that it is a punishment.

20.verse: His eyes should see his own ruin. He should drink from the wrath of the Almighty.

21.verse: How can he be interested in his family after he’s gone, when the number of his months is cut short?

22.verse: No One Understands How God Deals with Humans - “Can anyone teach God knowledge? Can anyone judge the Most High?

23.verse: One person dies in his prime and feels altogether happy and contented.

24.verse: His stomach is full of milk, and his bones are strong and healthy.

25.verse: Another person, never having tasted happiness, dies with a bitter soul.

26.verse: Together they lie down in the dust, and worms cover them.

27.verse: My Friends Have Betrayed Me - “You see, I know your thoughts and the schemes you plot against me

28.verse: because you ask, ‘Where is the house of the influential person? Where is the tent where wicked people live?’

29.verse: Haven’t you asked travelers? But you didn’t pay attention to their directions.

30.verse: On the day of disaster the wicked person is spared. On the day of ⌞God’s⌟ anger he is rescued.

31.verse: Who will tell him to his face how he lived? Who will pay him back for what he did?

32.verse: He is carried to the cemetery, and his grave is guarded.

33.verse: The soil in the creekbed is sweet to him. Everyone follows him. Countless others went before him.

34.verse: How can you comfort me with this nonsense when your answers continue to betray me?”

1.verse: Eliphaz Speaks: Admit You Are Wicked, Job - Then Eliphaz from Teman replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “Can a human be of any use to God when even a wise person is only useful to himself?

3.verse: Is the Almighty pleased when you are righteous? Does he gain anything when you follow the path of integrity?

4.verse: Does God correct you and bring you into a court of law because you fear him?

5.verse: “Aren’t you really very wicked? Is there no end to your wrongdoing?

6.verse: For no reason you take your brothers’ goods as security for a loan and strip them of their clothes.

7.verse: You don’t even give a tired person a drink of water, and you take food away from hungry people.

8.verse: A strong person owns the land. A privileged person lives in it.

9.verse: You send widows away empty-handed, and the arms of orphans are broken.

10.verse: That is why traps are all around you and great fear suddenly grips you.

11.verse: ⌞That is why⌟ darkness surrounds you and you cannot see and a flood of water covers you.

12.verse: “Isn’t God high above in the heavens? Look how high the highest stars are!

13.verse: You ask, ‘What does God know? Can he judge ⌞anything⌟ from behind a dark cloud?

14.verse: Thick clouds surround him so that he cannot see. He walks above the clouds.’

15.verse: “Are you following the old path that wicked people have taken?

16.verse: They are snatched up before their time. A river washes their foundation away.

17.verse: They told God, ‘Leave us alone! What can the Almighty do for us?’

18.verse: Yet, he filled their homes with good things. (The plan of the wicked is foreign to my way of thinking.)

19.verse: The righteous saw it and were glad, and the innocent made fun of them by saying,

20.verse: ‘Indeed, their wealth has been wiped out, and a fire has burned up what ⌞little⌟ they had left.’

21.verse: Make Peace with God - “Be in harmony and at peace with God. In this way you will have prosperity.

22.verse: Accept instruction from his mouth, and keep his words in your heart.

23.verse: If you return to the Almighty, you will prosper. If you put wrongdoing out of your tent,

24.verse: and lay your gold down in the dust, and put your gold from Ophir among the pebbles in the rivers,

25.verse: then the Almighty will become your gold and your large supply of silver.

26.verse: Then you will be happy with the Almighty and look up toward God.

27.verse: You will pray to him, and he will listen to you, and you will keep your vow to him.

28.verse: When you promise to do something, you will succeed, and light will shine on your path.

29.verse: When others are discouraged, you will say, ‘Cheer up!’ Then he will save the humble person.

30.verse: He will rescue one who is not innocent. That person will be rescued by your purity.”

1.verse: Job Speaks: Where Can I Find God? - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “My complaint is bitter again today. I try hard to control my sighing.

3.verse: “If only I knew where I could find God! I would go where he lives.

4.verse: I would present ⌞my⌟ case to him. I would have a mouthful of arguments.

5.verse: I want to know the words he would use to answer me. I want to understand the things he would say to me.

6.verse: Would he sue me and hide behind great legal maneuvers? No, he certainly would press charges against me.

7.verse: Then decent people could argue with him, and I would escape my judgment forever.

8.verse: However, if I go east, he isn’t there. If I go west, I can’t find him.

9.verse: If I go northward, where he is at work, I can’t observe him. If I turn southward, I can’t see him.

10.verse: ⌞I can’t find him⌟ because he knows the road I take. When he tests me, I’ll come out as pure as gold.

11.verse: I have followed his footsteps closely. I have stayed on his path and did not turn from it.

12.verse: I have not left his commands behind. I have treasured his words in my heart.

13.verse: God Is Against Me - “But God is one of a kind. Who can make him change his mind? He does whatever he wants!

14.verse: He will carry out ⌞his⌟ orders concerning me as he does with so many other things.

15.verse: That is why I’m terrified of him. When I think of it, I’m afraid of him.

16.verse: God has discouraged me. The Almighty has filled me with terror.

17.verse: But I am not silenced by the dark or by the thick darkness that covers my face.

1.verse: Job Continues: Why Doesn’t God Punish Those Who Do Evil? - “Why doesn’t the Almighty set aside times ⌞for punishment⌟? Why don’t those who are close to him see his days ⌞of judgment⌟?

2.verse: “⌞People⌟ move boundary markers. They steal flocks and tend them as shepherds.

3.verse: They drive away the orphan’s donkey. They take the widow’s ox as security for a loan.

4.verse: They force needy people off the road. All the poor people of the country go into hiding.

5.verse: Like wild donkeys in the desert, poor people go out to do their work, looking for food. The plains provide food for their children.

6.verse: They harvest animal food in the field ⌞to feed themselves⌟. They pick the leftover grapes in the wicked person’s vineyard.

7.verse: All night they lie naked without a covering from the cold.

8.verse: They are drenched by the rainstorms in the mountains. They hug the rocks because they can’t find shelter.

9.verse: “⌞People⌟ snatch the ⌞nursing⌟ orphan from a breast and take a poor woman’s baby as security for a loan.

10.verse: ⌞That is why⌟ the poor go around naked. They are hungry, yet they carry bundles of grain.

11.verse: They press out olive oil between rows ⌞of olive trees⌟. They stomp on grapes in wine vats, yet they are thirsty.

12.verse: Those dying in the city groan. Wounded people cry for help, but God pays no attention to their prayers.

13.verse: “Such people are among those who rebel against the light. They are not acquainted with its ways. They do not stay on its paths.

14.verse: At dawn murderers rise; they kill the poor and needy. At night they become thieves.

15.verse: Adulterers watch for twilight. They say, ‘No one is watching us,’ as they cover their faces.

16.verse: In the dark, they break into houses, ⌞but⌟ by day they lock themselves in. They do not ⌞even⌟ know the light,

17.verse: because morning and deep darkness are the same to them, because they are familiar with the terrors of deep darkness.

18.verse: Such people are like scum on the surface of the water. Their property is cursed in the land. People do not travel the road that goes to their vineyards.

19.verse: ⌞Just as⌟ drought and heat steal water from snow, so the grave steals people who sin.

20.verse: The womb forgets them. Worms feast on them. No one remembers them anymore, and wickedness is snapped like a twig.

21.verse: These men take advantage of childless women. These men show no kindness to widows.

22.verse: ⌞God⌟ will drag away ⌞these⌟ mighty men by his power. These people may prosper, but they will never feel secure about life.

23.verse: ⌞God⌟ may let them feel confident and self-reliant, but his eyes are on their ways.

24.verse: ⌞Such people⌟ may be prosperous for a little while, but then they’re gone. They are brought down low and disappear like everything else. They wither like heads of grain.

25.verse: “If it isn’t so, who can prove I’m a liar and show that my words are worthless?”

1.verse: Bildad Speaks: No One Is Righteous to God - Then Bildad from Shuah replied ⌞to Job⌟,

2.verse: “Authority and terror belong to God. He establishes peace in his high places.

3.verse: Is there any ⌞limit to the⌟ number of his troops? Is there anyone on whom his light does not rise?

4.verse: How can a person be righteous to God? How can anyone born of a woman be pure?

5.verse: Even the moon isn’t bright, and the stars aren’t pure in his sight.

6.verse: How much less pure is a mortal—who is only a maggot— a descendant of Adam—who is only a worm!”

1.verse: Job Speaks: My Friends Have Offered Useless Advice - Then Job replied ⌞to his friends⌟,

2.verse: “You have helped the person who has no power and saved the arm that isn’t strong.

3.verse: You have advised the person who has no wisdom and offered so much assistance.

4.verse: To whom have you spoken ⌞these⌟ words, and whose spirit has spoken through you?

5.verse: God’s Power over Creation - “The souls of the dead tremble beneath the water, and so do the creatures living there.

6.verse: Sheol is naked in God’s presence, and Abaddon has no clothing.

7.verse: “He stretches out his heavens over empty space. He hangs the earth on nothing whatsoever.

8.verse: He holds the water in his thick clouds, and the clouds don’t ⌞even⌟ split under its ⌞weight⌟.

9.verse: He covers his throne by spreading his cloud over it.

10.verse: He marks the horizon on the surface of the water at the boundary where light meets dark.

11.verse: The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished when he yells at them.

12.verse: With his power he calmed the sea. With his insight he killed Rahab ⌞the sea monster⌟.

13.verse: With his wind the sky was cleared. With his hand he stabbed the fleeing snake.

14.verse: “These are only glimpses of what he does. We ⌞only⌟ hear a whisper of him! Who can understand the thunder of his power?”

1.verse: Job Continues: I Insist I Am Innocent - Job continued his poems and said,

2.verse: “I swear an oath by God, the one who has taken away my rights, by the Almighty, who has made my life bitter:

3.verse: ‘As long as there is one breath ⌞left⌟ in me and God’s breath fills my nostrils,

4.verse: my lips will not say anything wrong, and my tongue will not mumble anything deceitful.’

5.verse: It’s unthinkable for me to admit that you are right. Until I breathe my last breath, I will never give up my claim of integrity.

6.verse: I cling to my righteousness and won’t let go. My conscience won’t accuse me as long as I live.

7.verse: “Let my enemy be ⌞treated⌟ like wicked people. Let anyone who attacks me be ⌞treated⌟ like unrighteous people.

8.verse: After all, what hope does the godless person have when he is cut off, when God takes away his life?

9.verse: Will God hear his cry when trouble comes upon him?

10.verse: Can he be happy with the Almighty? Can he call on God at all times?

11.verse: What God Has in Store for Wicked People - “I will teach you about God’s power. I will not hide what the Almighty has done.

12.verse: Certainly, you have all seen it. Why then do you chatter on about such nonsense?

13.verse: This is what God has waiting for the wicked person, the inheritance that tyrants receive from the Almighty:

14.verse: If he has many children, swords will kill them, and his descendants won’t have enough food.

15.verse: Those who survive him will be buried by a plague, and their widows won’t cry ⌞for them⌟.

16.verse: Though he collects silver like dust and piles up clothing like dirt,

17.verse: righteous people will wear what he piles up, and the innocent will divide the silver ⌞among themselves⌟.

18.verse: He builds his house like a moth, like a shack that a watchman makes.

19.verse: He may go to bed rich, but he’ll never be rich again. When he opens his eyes, nothing will be left.

20.verse: Terrors overtake him like a flood. A windstorm snatches him away at night.

21.verse: The east wind carries him away, and he’s gone. It sweeps him from his place.

22.verse: It hurls itself at him without mercy. He flees from its power.

23.verse: It claps its hands over him. It whistles at him from his own place.

1.verse: Job Continues: Wisdom Is Inaccessible to Humans - “There is a place where silver is mined and a place where gold is refined.

2.verse: Iron is taken from the ground, and rocks are melted for ⌞their⌟ copper.

3.verse: ⌞Humans⌟ bring an end to darkness ⌞there⌟ and search to the limit of the gloomy, pitch-black rock.

4.verse: They open up a mineshaft far from civilization, where no one has set foot. ⌞In this shaft⌟ men dangle and swing back and forth.

5.verse: “Above the ground food grows, but beneath it the food decays as if ⌞it were burned⌟ by fire.

6.verse: That place’s stones are sapphire. Its dust contains gold.

7.verse: No bird of prey knows the way to it. No hawk’s eye has ever seen it.

8.verse: No proud beast has ever walked on it. No ferocious lion has ever passed over it.

9.verse: “Humans exert their power on the flinty rocks and overturn mountains at their base.

10.verse: They cut out mineshafts in the rocks. Their eyes see every precious thing.

11.verse: They explore the sources of rivers so that they bring hidden treasures to light.

12.verse: Wisdom Is Inaccessible to Decay and Death - “Where can wisdom be found? Where does understanding live?

13.verse: No mortal knows where it is. It cannot be found in this world of the living.

14.verse: The deep ocean says, ‘It isn’t in me.’ The sea says, ‘It isn’t with me.’

15.verse: You cannot obtain it with solid gold or buy it for any amount of silver.

16.verse: It can’t be bought with the gold from Ophir or with precious onyx or sapphire.

17.verse: Neither gold nor glass can equal its value. Nor can gold ornaments, jewels, or crystal

18.verse: be exchanged for it. Wisdom is more valuable than gems.

19.verse: Topaz from Ethiopia cannot equal its value. It cannot be bought for ⌞any amount of⌟ pure gold.

20.verse: “Where does wisdom come from? Where does understanding live?

21.verse: It is hidden from the eyes of every living being, hidden even from the birds in the air.

22.verse: Decay and Death say, ‘We’ve heard a rumor about it.’

23.verse: Wisdom Is Accessible Only to the Creator - “God understands the way to it. He knows where it lives

24.verse: because he can see to the ends of the earth and observe everything under heaven.

25.verse: When he gave the wind its force and measured the water ⌞in the sea⌟,

26.verse: when he made rules for the rain and set paths for the thunderstorms,

27.verse: then he saw it and announced it. He confirmed it and examined it.

28.verse: So he told humans, ‘The fear of the Lord is wisdom! To stay away from evil is understanding.’ ”

1.verse: Job Continues: My Glorious Past - Job continued his poems and said,

2.verse: “If only my life could be like it used to be, in the days when God watched over me,

3.verse: when he made his lamp shine on my head, when I walked through the dark in his light.

4.verse: If only I were in the prime of my life ⌞again⌟, when God was an adviser in my tent.

5.verse: When the Almighty was still with me and my children were around me,

6.verse: my steps were bathed in buttermilk, and the rocks poured streams of olive oil on me.

7.verse: When I went through the city gate and took my seat in the town square,

8.verse: young men saw me and kept out of sight. Old men stood up straight out of respect ⌞for me⌟.

9.verse: Princes held back ⌞their⌟ words and put their hands over their mouths.

10.verse: The voices of nobles were hushed, and their tongues stuck to the roofs of their mouths.

11.verse: “⌞Any⌟ ears that heard me blessed me. ⌞Any⌟ eyes that saw me spoke well of me,

12.verse: because I rescued the poor who called ⌞for help⌟ and the orphans who had no one to help them.

13.verse: I received a blessing from the dying. I made the widow’s heart sing for joy.

14.verse: I put on righteousness, and it was my clothing. I practiced justice, and it was my robe and my turban.

15.verse: I was eyes for the blind person. I was feet for the lame person.

16.verse: I was father to the needy. I carefully investigated cases brought by strangers.

17.verse: I broke the teeth of the wicked person and made him drop the prey out of his mouth.

18.verse: “I thought, ‘I may die in my own house, but I will make my days as numerous as the sand.

19.verse: My roots will grow toward the water, and dew will lie on my branches all night.

20.verse: My power will be fresh ⌞every day⌟, and the bow in my hand will remain new.’

21.verse: “People listened to me eagerly, quietly waiting for my advice.

22.verse: After I had spoken, they wouldn’t speak again. After all, my words fell gently on them.

23.verse: They were as eager to hear me as they were for rain. They opened their mouths wide as if waiting for a spring shower.

24.verse: When I smiled at them, they could hardly believe it, but the expression on my face did not change.

25.verse: I decided how they should live. I sat as their leader. I lived like a king among his troops, like one who comforts mourners.

1.verse: Job Talks about His Present Misery - “But now those who are younger than I am laugh at me. I didn’t think their fathers were fit to sit with the dogs of my flock.

2.verse: Of what use to me was the strength of their hands? Their strength is gone.

3.verse: Shriveled up from need and hunger, they gnaw at the dry and barren ground during the night.

4.verse: They pick saltwort from the underbrush, and the roots of the broom plant are their food.

5.verse: They are driven from the community. People shout at them in the same way they shout at thieves.

6.verse: They have to live in dry riverbeds, in holes in the ground, and among rocks.

7.verse: They howl in bushes and huddle together under thornbushes.

8.verse: Godless fools and worthless people are forced out of the land with whips.

9.verse: “And now they make fun of me with songs. I have become a joke to them.

10.verse: Since they consider me disgusting, they keep their distance from me and don’t hesitate to spit in my face.

11.verse: Because God has untied my cord and has made me suffer, they are no longer restrained in my presence.

12.verse: They have attacked me on my right side like a mob. They trip my feet and then prepare ways to destroy me.

13.verse: Yes, they remove all traces of my path in order to destroy me. No one is there to help me against them.

14.verse: They come through a wide hole ⌞in the wall⌟. They crawl through the ruins.

15.verse: Terrors are directed toward me. They blow away my dignity like the wind. My prosperity vanishes like a cloud.

16.verse: “Now my life is pouring out of me. Days of suffering seize me.

17.verse: At night God pierces my bones. My body doesn’t rest.

18.verse: With great strength he grabs my clothes. He seizes me by the collar of my robe.

19.verse: He throws me into the dirt so that I become like dust and ashes.

20.verse: Job Calls on God for Help - “I call to you for help, but you don’t answer me. I stand up, but you just look at me.

21.verse: You have begun to treat me cruelly. With your mighty hand you assault me.

22.verse: You pick me up and let the wind carry me away. You toss me around with a storm.

23.verse: I know you will lead me to death, to the dwelling place appointed for all living beings.

24.verse: Job Says: I Am Being Punished by God - “But God doesn’t stretch out his hand against one who is ruined when that person calls for help in his disaster.

25.verse: Didn’t I cry for the person whose days were difficult? Didn’t my soul grieve for the poor?

26.verse: When I waited for good, evil came. When I looked for light, darkness came.

27.verse: My insides are churning and won’t calm down. Days of misery are ahead of me.

28.verse: I walk in the dark without the sun. I stand up in public and call for help.

29.verse: I’m a brother to jackals and a companion of ostriches.

30.verse: My skin turns dark and peels. My body burns with fever.

31.verse: So my lyre is used for mourning and my flute for loud weeping.

1.verse: Job Wonders What Sin He May Have Committed - “I have made an agreement with my eyes. Then how can I look with lust at a virgin?

2.verse: What would God above do ⌞to me⌟? What would be my inheritance from the Almighty on high?

3.verse: Aren’t there catastrophes for wicked people and disasters for those who do wrong?

4.verse: Doesn’t he see my ways and count all my steps?

5.verse: “If I have walked with lies or my feet have run after deception,

6.verse: ⌞then⌟ let God weigh me on honest scales, and he will know I have integrity.

7.verse: “If my steps have left the ⌞proper⌟ path, or my heart has followed ⌞the desire of⌟ my eyes, or my hands are stained ⌞with sin⌟,

8.verse: ⌞then⌟ let someone else eat what I have planted, and let my crops be uprooted.

9.verse: “If I have been seduced by a woman or I have secretly waited near my neighbor’s door,

10.verse: ⌞then⌟ let my wife grind for another ⌞man⌟, and let other ⌞men⌟ kneel over her.

11.verse: That would be a scandal, and that would be a criminal offense.

12.verse: It would be a fire that burns even in Abaddon. It would uproot my entire harvest.

13.verse: “If I have abused the rights of my servants, male or female, when they have disagreed with me,

14.verse: then what could I do if God rises up? If he examines me, how could I answer him?

15.verse: Didn’t he who made me in my mother’s belly make them? Didn’t the same God form us in the womb?

16.verse: “If I have refused the requests of the poor or made a widow’s eyes stop ⌞looking for help⌟,

17.verse: or have eaten my food alone without letting the orphan eat any of it….

18.verse: (From my youth the orphan grew up with me as though I were his father, and from my birth I treated the widow kindly.)

19.verse: If I have seen anyone die because he had no clothes or a poor person going naked….

20.verse: (If his body didn’t bless me, or the wool from my sheep didn’t keep him warm….)

21.verse: If I have shaken my fist at an orphan because I knew that others would back me up in court,

22.verse: ⌞then⌟ let my shoulder fall out of its socket, and let my arm be broken at the elbow.

23.verse: “A disaster from God terrifies me. In the presence of his majesty I can do nothing.

24.verse: “If I put my confidence in gold or said to fine gold, ‘I trust you’….

25.verse: If I enjoyed being very rich because my hand had found great ⌞wealth⌟….

26.verse: If I saw the light shine or the moon move along in its splendor

27.verse: so that my heart was secretly tempted, and I threw them a kiss with my hand,

28.verse: then that, too, would be a criminal offense, and I would have denied God above.

29.verse: “If I enjoyed the ruin of my enemy or celebrated when harm came to him

30.verse: (even though I didn’t speak sinfully by calling down a curse on his life)….

31.verse: “If the people who were in my tent had said, ‘We wish we had never filled ⌞our stomachs⌟ with his food’….

32.verse: (The visitor never spent the night outside, because I opened my door to the traveler.)

33.verse: “If I have covered my disobedience like Adam and kept my sin to myself,

34.verse: because I dreaded the large, noisy crowd and because the contempt of the ⌞local⌟ mobs terrified me so that I kept quiet and didn’t go outside….

35.verse: “If only I had someone who would listen to me! Look, here is my signature! Let the Almighty answer me. Let the prosecutor write ⌞his complaint⌟ on a scroll.

36.verse: I would certainly carry it on my shoulder and place it on my head like a crown.

37.verse: I would tell him the number of my steps and approach him like a prince.

38.verse: “If my land has cried out against me, and its furrows have wept….

39.verse: If I have eaten its produce without paying for it and made its owners breathe their last,

40.verse: ⌞then⌟ let it grow thistles instead of wheat, and foul-smelling weeds instead of barley.” This is the end of Job’s words.

1.verse: Elihu Decides to Speak to Job - These three men stopped answering Job because Job thought he was righteous.

2.verse: Then Elihu, son of Barachel, a descendant of Buz from the family of Ram, became very angry with Job because Job thought he was more righteous than God.

3.verse: Elihu was also very angry with Job’s three friends because they had found no answer. They made it look as if God were wrong.

4.verse: Elihu waited as they spoke to Job because they were older than he was.

5.verse: When Elihu saw that the three men had no further responses, he became very angry.

6.verse: Elihu Speaks: the Reason for Elihu’s Discourse - So Elihu, son of Barachel, the descendant of Buz, replied ⌞to Job⌟, “I am young, and you are old. That’s why I refrained from speaking and was afraid to tell you what I know.

7.verse: I thought, ‘Age should speak, and experience should teach wisdom.’

8.verse: However, there is in humans a Spirit, the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.

9.verse: People do not become wise merely because they live long. They don’t understand what justice is merely because they’re old.

10.verse: “That is why I say, ‘Listen to me! Let me tell you what I know.’

11.verse: I waited for you to speak. I listened for you to share your understanding until you could find the right words.

12.verse: I’ve paid close attention to you, but none of you refuted Job. None of you has an answer to what he says.

13.verse: So don’t say, ‘We’ve found wisdom. Let God, not humans, defeat him.’

14.verse: Job did not choose his words to refute me, so I won’t answer him with your speeches.

15.verse: “Job’s friends have been overwhelmed and don’t have any more answers. They don’t have another word to say.

16.verse: Should I wait because they don’t speak, because they stand there and don’t have any more answers?

17.verse: “I’ll give my answer. I’ll tell you what I know.

18.verse: I’m full of words. The Spirit within me forces me ⌞to speak⌟.

19.verse: My belly is like ⌞a bottle of⌟ wine that has not been opened, like new wineskins that are ready to burst.

20.verse: I must speak to get relief. I must open my mouth and answer.

21.verse: I won’t be partial toward anyone or flatter anyone.

22.verse: I don’t know how to flatter. If I did, my maker would soon carry me away.

1.verse: Elihu Continues: Listen, Job - “Please, Job, listen to my words and consider everything I say.

2.verse: I’ve opened my mouth. The words are on the tip of my tongue.

3.verse: My words are straight from the heart, and I sincerely speak the knowledge that is on my lips.

4.verse: “God’s Spirit has made me. The breath of the Almighty gives me life.

5.verse: Answer me if you can. Present your case to me, and take your stand.

6.verse: Indeed, I stand in front of God as you do. I, too, was formed from a piece of clay.

7.verse: You certainly don’t need to be terrified of me. I won’t put too much pressure on you.

8.verse: God Doesn’t Have to Answer You, Job - “But you spoke directly to me, and I listened to your words.

9.verse: ⌞You said,⌟ ‘I’m pure—without any rebellious acts ⌞against God⌟. I’m clean; I have no sin.

10.verse: God is only looking for an excuse to attack me. He considers me his enemy.

11.verse: He puts my feet in the stocks and watches all my paths.’

12.verse: You aren’t right about this! I’ve got an answer for you: God is greater than any mortal.
